newsitem.title: UK: Five injured in Channel Tunnel train fire.
newsitem.headline: Five injured in Channel Tunnel train fire.

text.p: Five truck drivers were hurt on Monday night after a fire broke out in a truck being transported on a train through the Channel Tunnel from Britain to France.

"The five men have been taken to hospital," a spokesman for channel tunnel operator Eurotunnel told Reuters. "The train is still on fire. It is being tackled by both the French and British fire fighting services," the spokeswoman added.

The 35 mile long (51 km) tunnnel linking England and France was closed after the freight-shuttle train, used to transport trucks and their drivers, was evacuated just after 9 p.m. (same GMT) with the carriages around 12 miles (19 km) from the French end of the tunnel.
The fire broke out toward the back of the 730 metre (yard) long train, which can carry up to 28 large trucks, the Eurotunnel spokeswoman said.
"It is the first time the tunnel has been closed for an emergency. We have had safety drills in the past but this is the first real event," she said.
Thirty one passengers were evacuated from the northbound tunnel to a central service shaft and then transported via another shuttle train back to France via the southbound tunnel.
Three of the injured truck drivers were taken to a hospital in Calais and the other two were in hospital in Lille, the spokeswoman said.

Eurotunnel said they did not know when the tunnel would be opened for passenger traffic. "We do not know exactly what damage has been caused because the firefighters are still dealing with it," the spokeswoman said.
"Both the French and the Kent(British) fire services they are making steady progress fighting the fire but it is not completely out yet," she said.
